newsitem.title: UGANDA: Weak coffee price lowers Uganda export income.
newsitem.headline: Weak coffee price lowers Uganda export income.

text.p: Uganda's export earnings fell by nearly 4.0 percent in the financial year to June 30 because of weak world prices for its key coffee exports, the Finance Ministry said on Friday.
Export revenue fell to $555.3 million in 1995/96 from $577.5 million the year before, the ministry said in a report.
"The major factor behind the decline in overall exports was the sharp drop in the world prices of coffee, after more than doubling between the period 1993/94 and 1994/95," it said.
"The big increase in the volume of coffee exports of about 32.5 percent in 1995/96 over the previous year was not enough to compensate fully for the fall in prices," it added.

Uganda's coffee exports in 1995/96 rose to 3.84 million 60-kg (132 lb) bags from 2.89 million in the previous year due to better weather and the maturing of a new prolific coffee type planted three years ago, according to official records.
But low world prices meant coffee exports fetched only $392.61 million in 1995/96, compared with $442.16 million in 1994/95, the records showed.
Despite this, coffee contributed a high 70.0 percent of Uganda's total export revenues, even though this was down from 76.6 percent the year before, the ministry said.
Uganda has been trying to boost other exports like cotton, tea, tobacco and flowers to make its reviving economy less dependent on world coffee prices.
In 1995/96, rising export earners included fish, second only to coffee, and bringing in $29.88 million, up from $16.99 million in 1994/95, the report said.
Other key exports were cotton, $12.16 million; hides and skins, $9.65 million; tobacco, $9.24 million; tea, $8.75 million, cereals $7.71 million and beans $6.73 million.
The government is trying to promote exports of vanilla, flowers, oil seeds, cocoa, animal skins, silkworm and tropical fruits as an alternative to the "traditional" export crops.
But production of these remains low, and economists say it will be a long time before they make a serious contribution.

Coffee is expected to dominate this year's exports too. Industry analysts say coffee exports for the current crop year (October-September), will rise to 3.8 million bags from 2.76 million in the last year, and could climb to 4.2 million bags in 1996/97, they say.
